conclusion: To solve the problem, we need to determine the horizontal distance \( s \) traveled by the person and the motorcycle from the platform to point \( A \).
The motorcycle leaves the platform with a horizontal velocity \( v = 3 \, \text{m/s} \) and a vertical height \( h = 0.8 \, \text{m} \).
The vertical motion is under gravity, so the time \( t \) to fall the height \( h \) is given by \( h = \frac{1}{2} g t^2 \).
The horizontal distance \( s \) traveled by the motorcycle is \( s = v t = 3 \times 0.4 = 1.2 \, \text{m} \).
The motorcycle lands on the ground and then slides down the circular track. The speed at point \( A \) can be found using the conservation of energy.
The vertical component of the velocity when the motorcycle lands is \( v_y = g t = 10 \times 0.4 = 4 \, \text{m/s} \).
The total speed at the landing point is \( v_{\text{land}} = \sqrt{v^2 + v_y^2} = \sqrt{3^2 + 4^2} = \sqrt{9 + 16} = \sqrt{25} = 5 \, \text{m/s} \).
The speed at point \( A \) is the same as the speed at the landing point because the track is smooth and there is no friction. Therefore, the speed at point \( A \) is \( 5 \, \text{m/s} \).
The speed at point \( A \) is \( 5 \, \text{m/s} \) and the radius of the circular track is \( R = 1.0 \, \text{m} \).
The speed at point \( A \) must satisfy the condition for the circular motion: \( v_A = \sqrt{g R \sin \theta} \).
This is not possible since the sine function can only take values between -1 and 1. This indicates an error in the interpretation or the problem setup.
